On Earth, biofilms are associated with 65% and 80% of infectious and chronic diseases . Materials can profoundly influence biofilm growth .

There were no differentially expressed genes (DEG) between SS316 and pSS316 biofilms in any conditions tested . No morphological differences were observed between the two materials .

The PA14 liquid cultures in which the coupons were submerged became more turbid (turbidity correlation with viable cell count) for the microgravity set than for the 1 <em>g <a>g controls (not significant for SS day 1 and SS day 2)

Table 1 shows the results of LIS day 3 . Table 1: P.A. A. G. H. G., H. H., H., G., G. A., H, G. J., H . H, H. J. H, J. G, G, H, P. H . G, P, H . A. H is a
P. aeruginosa biofilms formed on SS in space with respect to Earth . There was no significant effect >2-fold in resistome .

Genes involved in apoptosis were differentially expressed on LIS biofilms . In the resistome, gene <em>nouJ had 2.2-fold increased expression on the LIS . In addition, genes involved in . apoptosis [PA2645] and the antitoxins [PA4674] and PA14_21720 [PA2489]

The following paragraphs describe the results of gene expression analyses performed to compare biofilms grown on SS for 3 days with respect to 1-day-old biofilmms . The first paragraph focuses on results under Earth’s gravity and the second paragraph for results in microgravity .

In microgravity, we observed less robust biofilms in terms of biomass, thickness, and surface area coverage in microgravity . Such an environment could be partially attributed to the increased planktonic cell growth in micro gravity, increasing the accumulation of metabolic byproducts .
P. aeruginosa had increased production of pyoverdine in the first days of microgravity . Biofilms in microgravity had no increased expression of pyorubin .

On LIS, biofilm’s reduced expression of LPS-related genes (on Earth and in microgravity) and increased expression of alginate (only on Earth) could be related to the presence of nucleic acid repulsion forces .

Growing biofilms over LIS could affect virulence and antimicrobial resistance . But predicting such an effect is complicated as there is gene expression evidence for increasing and decreasing effects .
LIS seems to prevent the first stage of biofilm formation: cell attachment . More tests and analysis are needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind this phenomenon .

144 samples were prepared, 72 for flight and 72 for corresponding ground controls . Each gravitational condition tested three material surfaces (SS316, pSS316 and LIS), three biofilm incubation times (1, 2, or 3 days), and two termination reagents (PFA for morphology analysis and RNAlater for transcriptomics)

Flight samples were sent to the ISS on the Cygnus NG-12 spacecraft . Eight FPAs with the three-chamber configuration were assembled into each GAP and transferred to 4 °C . Samples were incubated at 37 C inside BioServe’s Space Automated Bioproduct Lab (SABL) for the designated incubation times

The samples were stained with PI [15 µM] (PromoKine Cat. PK-CA707-40017 diluted with water) for 15 min and with FilmTracer™ FM™ 1-43 Green Biofilm (Invitrogen Cat. F10317) for 30 mins under light-protected conditions . After each stain the samples
